head.title: El Nino Persuades The Deserts to Bloom

hedline.hl1: El Nino Persuades The Deserts to Bloom

abstract.p: El Nino rains have tranformed Mojave and Sonoran Deserts in California and Arizona into colorful gardens of flowers; Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument west of Tucson has had best blooming season since 1983 (S)

block.p: The heavy rains in California this winter, while certainly destructive and sometimes deadly, have spawned a riot of life in the desert that has not been matched for several years. Normally arid and sunburned, the Mojave and Sonoran Deserts have been transformed into colorful gardens of flowers. At many Southern California and Arizona parks, staff members report extraordinary landscapes of blooming verbena, primrose and brittle bush. In some places, cactus are flowering among the thorns until the petals wither away in the heat in late spring.

At Death Valley National Park, (760) 786-2331, the bloom is generally at its height at the end of March. But in Titus Canyon and other higher elevations, flowers like Indian paintbrush blossom through April and May.

The California Poppy Reserve, (805) 724-1180, 80 miles north of Los Angeles, is having a showy poppy bloom this season on its 1,700 acres of buttes and rolling hills. The flowers make an ocean of orange that typically crests in mid-April.

The Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, (520) 387-6849), 145 miles west of Tucson in Arizona, has had the best blooming season since 1983, a spokesman said. The organ pipe cactus is among the most unusual of the desert flowers, branching out like a carrot top, with pink petals that open only at night from mid-May to mid-July.
